articles.headline: Navient agrees to cancel 66,000 student borrowers’ loans to settle claims of predatory lending.
articles.snippet: The student loan servicer agreed to cancel $1.7 billion in private student loan debts for nearly 66,000 borrowers and to pay $95 million in restitution.
articles.abstract: The student loan servicer agreed to cancel $1.7 billion in private student loan debts for nearly 66,000 borrowers and to pay $95 million in restitution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Navient, once one of the country’s largest student loan servicing companies, reached a $1.85 billion deal with 39 states to settle claims that it had made predatory loans that saddled borrowers with crushing debts they were highly unlikely to repay.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Sinema Rejects Changing Filibuster, Dealing Biden a Setback
articles.snippet: Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s comments came after the House approved a set of voting rights measures on a party-line vote of 220 to 203.
articles.abstract: Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s comments came after the House approved a set of voting rights measures on a party-line vote of 220 to 203.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s campaign to push new voting rights protections through Congress appeared all but dead on Thursday, after it became clear that he had failed to unite his own party behind his drive to overhaul Senate rules to enact the legislation over Republican opposition.

articles.headline: Before Elections, Georgia Republicans Again Consider Voting Restrictions
articles.snippet: A sweeping 2021 law drew a legal complaint from the Justice Department. Legislators in the state are considering several new measures focused on ballot access and fraud investigations.
articles.abstract: A sweeping 2021 law drew a legal complaint from the Justice Department. Legislators in the state are considering several new measures focused on ballot access and fraud investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Butch Miller, a Republican leader of the Georgia State Senate, is running for lieutenant governor and faces a tough fight this spring against a primary opponent backed by former President Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Oath Keepers Leader Charged With Seditious Conspiracy in Jan. 6 Investigation
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. arrested Stewart Rhodes, the founder of the far-right militia, in a major step forward in the investigation into the attack on the Capitol by supporters of Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. arrested Stewart Rhodes, the founder of the far-right militia, in a major step forward in the investigation into the attack on the Capitol by supporters of Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stewart Rhodes, the leader and founder of the far-right Oath Keepers militia, was arrested on Thursday and charged along with 10 others with seditious conspiracy over what prosecutors said was their wide-ranging plot to storm the Capitol on Jan. 6 last year and disrupt the certification of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s electoral victory.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Supreme Court Blocks Biden’s Virus Mandate for Large Employers
articles.snippet: But the justices allowed a vaccination requirement for health care workers at facilities that receive federal money.
articles.abstract: But the justices allowed a vaccination requirement for health care workers at facilities that receive federal money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday blocked the Biden administration from enforcing a vaccine-or-testing mandate for large employers, dealing a blow to a key element of the White House’s plan to address the pandemic as coronavirus cases resulting from the Omicron variant are on the rise.

articles.headline: Price Controls Set Off Heated Debate as History Gets a Second Look
articles.snippet: A discussion over whether price controls would work to stem inflation is sweeping progressives. So far, it has little political acceptance.
articles.abstract: A discussion over whether price controls would work to stem inflation is sweeping progressives. So far, it has little political acceptance.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s recent inflation spike has prompted renewed interest in an idea that many economists and policy experts thought they had long ago left behind for good: price controls.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Murder, Torture, Rape: A Landmark Conviction on State Violence in Syria
articles.snippet: A German court found a former Syrian intelligence officer guilty of crimes against humanity and sentenced him to life in prison — a first after a decade of war.
articles.abstract: A German court found a former Syrian intelligence officer guilty of crimes against humanity and sentenced him to life in prison — a first after a decade of war.
articles.lead_paragraph: When detainees arrived at the security office in Syria, it “welcomed” them with an hour of whipping or beating, they told a German court.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: New Virus Cases Begin to Slow in U.S. Cities Where Omicron Hit First
articles.snippet: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.
articles.abstract: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.
articles.lead_paragraph: At another bleak moment of the pandemic in the United States — with nearly 800,000 new cases a day, deaths rising and federal medical teams deploying to overwhelmed hospitals — glints of progress have finally started to emerge. In a handful of places that were among the first to see a surge of the Omicron variant last month, reports of new coronavirus infections have started to level off or decline.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith, Campbell Robertson and Sabrina Imbler

articles.headline: Critics Say I.M.F. Loan Fees Are Hurting Nations in Desperate Need
articles.snippet: Democratic lawmakers say the global fund’s surcharges for emergency relief siphon away money that countries need to fight the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Democratic lawmakers say the global fund’s surcharges for emergency relief siphon away money that countries need to fight the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when the coronavirus pandemic is fueling a rapid rise in inequality and debt, a growing number of policymakers and economists are pressuring the International Monetary Fund to eliminate extra fees it charges on loans to struggling nations because they siphon away scarce funds that could instead be used to battle Covid.

articles.headline: Taking On Starbucks, Inspired by Bernie Sanders
articles.snippet: The liberal workers the company has long attracted are expanding a union campaign to other cities after a landmark victory in Buffalo.
articles.abstract: The liberal workers the company has long attracted are expanding a union campaign to other cities after a landmark victory in Buffalo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maggie Carter, a Starbucks barista in Knoxville, Tenn., is a warm and reassuring presence who says she is keen to “go the extra mile” for customers.

articles.headline: Oil Producers Aren’t Keeping Up With Demand, Causing Prices to Stay High
articles.snippet: OPEC Plus, the United States and others have been slow to ramp up output, lagging production goals.
articles.abstract: OPEC Plus, the United States and others have been slow to ramp up output, lagging production goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly two years ago the world’s oil producers slammed on the brakes and drastically cut production as the pandemic gripped the world’s economies. The sharp pullback came with an implicit promise that as factories reopened and planes returned to the air, the oil industry would revive, too, gradually scaling up production to help economies return to prepandemic health.

articles.headline: No Shots, No Day Care: Parents of Kids Under 5 Stuck in Grueling Limbo
articles.snippet: Facing an uncontrolled surge of virus cases, parents of young children are again forced to wrestle with child care crises as the rest of the world appears eager to move on.
articles.abstract: Facing an uncontrolled surge of virus cases, parents of young children are again forced to wrestle with child care crises as the rest of the world appears eager to move on.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Twice last year, Margaret Schulte and her husband, Jason Abercrombie, traveled 11 hours round-trip to Louisiana from their home in Tulsa, Okla., in the hopes of vaccinating their children, who were 2 and 4, against the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman and Giulia Heyward

articles.headline: When Tennis Became a Stage for Right and Wrong During a Pandemic
articles.snippet: The move to deport Novak Djokovic is not just an exercise of Australian law. It represents an enforcement of collectivist values against an athlete who sought to play by his own rules.
articles.abstract: The move to deport Novak Djokovic is not just an exercise of Australian law. It represents an enforcement of collectivist values against an athlete who sought to play by his own rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — What began as a power struggle between a defiantly unvaccinated tennis star and a prime minister seeking a distraction from his own pre-election missteps has turned into something far weightier: a public stand for pandemic rules and the collective good.

articles.headline: Millions Have Lost a Step Into the Middle Class, Researchers Say
articles.snippet: The new figure points to the challenge for the majority of Americans who do not have a four-year college degree.
articles.abstract: The new figure points to the challenge for the majority of Americans who do not have a four-year college degree.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last two decades, workers without four-year college degrees have lost ground in the occupations that used to be ladders to middle-class lives for them and their families.

articles.headline: Retail sales fell in December, a slowdown in a robust holiday shopping season.
articles.snippet: Despite that 1.9 percent decline, sales for the fourth quarter of 2021 jumped 17.1 percent as consumers began their holiday shopping earlier.
articles.abstract: Despite that 1.9 percent decline, sales for the fourth quarter of 2021 jumped 17.1 percent as consumers began their holiday shopping earlier.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retail sales fell 1.9 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported on Friday, reflecting a slowdown during an otherwise robust holiday shopping season that started earlier in the year for many consumers.
